text: He sent Moses his servant; and Aaron whom he had chosen.
text_kjv: He sent Moses his servant; and Aaron whom he had chosen.
text_niv: He sent Moses his servant,and Aaron, whom he had chosen.
text_esv: He sent Moses, his servant, and Aaron, whom he had chosen.
text_nlt: But the LORD sent his servant Moses,along with Aaron, whom he had chosen.
text_msg: Then he sent his servant Moses,and Aaron, whom he also chose.
text_nasb: He sent Moses His servant, [And] Aaron, whom He had chosen.
context: Psalm 105 is a historical psalm, recounting God's faithfulness to Israel from the time of Abraham through the wilderness wanderings. Understanding the context of Exodus is crucial. The Israelites were enslaved in Egypt for generations, facing brutal oppression. Pharaoh, considered a god-king, controlled every aspect of their lives. The Egyptians worshipped a pantheon of gods, each believed to control different aspects of nature and human affairs. During this time, the role of a servant in ancient Near Eastern societies was often one of complete subservience. A 'servant' of a king held immense power and responsibility, acting as his representative. Moses' background is particularly important: raised in Pharaoh's household, yet identifying with his Hebrew roots, he was uniquely positioned to mediate between God and both Pharaoh and the Israelites. Aaron, Moses’ brother, was skilled in public speaking, a necessary complement to Moses’ sometimes reluctant leadership. The phrase 'whom he had chosen' emphasizes divine sovereignty in selecting Aaron for the priestly role. This selection was not based on merit or lineage at that time but on God’s specific will for Israel’s future worship and governance.
meaning: This verse highlights God's initiative in delivering His people. 'He sent' emphasizes divine action; God wasn't passively observing, but actively intervening in human history. Moses, designated as 'his servant,' signifies a deep relationship of trust and obedience. It implies Moses acted on God's authority and carried out His will. The term 'servant' here denotes not just a menial laborer, but a trusted agent, empowered to act on behalf of the master. Choosing Aaron is equally significant. Aaron's role as a priest, especially his ability to speak eloquently on behalf of Moses, was crucial for communicating God’s message and performing the necessary rituals. 'Whom he had chosen' emphasizes God's sovereign selection. It underscores that spiritual leadership is not a matter of human aspiration or inheritance but of divine appointment. God equips those He calls. This verse foreshadows the concept of mediation, pointing towards Christ, the ultimate servant and chosen one, who mediates between God and humanity. God’s choice of both men also reinforces the concept of complementary leadership; different gifts and skills are needed to fulfill God’s purposes. Their partnership highlights the body of Christ and how different gifts are necessary for the church to function effectively.
application: In our own lives, Psalm 105:26 offers several profound applications. Firstly, it reminds us that God is actively involved in our lives, even when we are in difficult or seemingly hopeless situations. Just as He sent Moses and Aaron to deliver the Israelites, He sends help and guidance to us, often through unexpected sources. We should be attentive to the ways God is working around us, even in subtle ways. Secondly, it challenges us to consider how we can be servants of God. Like Moses, this may involve stepping outside of our comfort zones and taking on challenging tasks. Like Aaron, it may involve using our gifts and talents to support and uplift others. We might not feel qualified or adequate, but God equips those He calls. This verse also speaks to the importance of recognizing and affirming the gifts of others. We are called to encourage and support those whom God has placed in leadership roles, understanding that their calling is divinely appointed. Furthermore, this passage encourages us to pray for our leaders, both spiritual and secular, asking God to grant them wisdom and discernment. We should strive to live lives of obedience and service, recognizing that our actions can have a significant impact on the lives of others. The collaborative nature of Moses and Aaron underscores the value of teamwork and partnership within the church and in our communities. We should seek to work together, using our diverse gifts and talents to advance God's kingdom.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for your active involvement in our lives and in the world. Thank you for sending Jesus, your ultimate servant and chosen one, to redeem us. Help us to recognize your hand at work in our lives and to be open to your leading. Give us the courage to step out in faith and to use our gifts to serve you and others. Help us to recognize and affirm the gifts of those around us, especially those in leadership. We lift up our leaders to you, asking for your guidance and wisdom in their decisions. May we be a people who are known for our obedience, our service, and our unity, all for your glory. Amen.

faqs.answer: The verse mentions both Moses and Aaron to emphasize the importance of their complementary roles. Moses was the primary leader and spoke to God, while Aaron acted as his spokesperson and high priest. Their combined efforts were crucial for the liberation and spiritual guidance of Israel.
faqs.question: Q1: Why does the verse specifically mention both Moses and Aaron?

faqs.answer: Being a 'servant' of God means dedicating one's life to obeying His will and serving His purposes. It involves humility, obedience, and a willingness to put God's desires above one's own, reflecting a deep trust and dependence on Him.
faqs.question: Q2: What does it mean to be a 'servant' of God?

faqs.answer: This verse prefigures Jesus, who is the ultimate 'servant' of God. He was sent by God to redeem humanity from sin, mirroring Moses' role as a deliverer. Jesus was also 'chosen' by God, fulfilling the prophecies of the Messiah.
faqs.question: Q3: How does this verse relate to Jesus?

faqs.answer: 'Whom he had chosen' signifies God's sovereign selection and appointment. It underscores that Aaron's role as a priest was not based on merit or lineage but on God's specific will and purpose for the nation of Israel.
faqs.question: Q4: What does 'whom he had chosen' signify?

faqs.answer: You can apply this verse by recognizing God's active involvement in your life, being open to serving Him in whatever capacity He calls you to, and affirming the gifts and roles of others within your community and church.
